newsitem.title: USA: Colorado voters split over prospect of road tax.
newsitem.headline: Colorado voters split over prospect of road tax.

text.p: Colorado residents are evenly divided over supporting a tax increase to improve the state's deteriorating roads, a poll published on Monday showed.

Of 600 registered voters, some 46 percent would oppose a tax to improve highways, while 42 percent would support it and 12 percent were undecided, according to a poll conducted by the Rocky Mountain News and KMGH-TV. The margin of error was four percentage points.
Younger people appeared more likely to favor the tax, the newspaper said. The poll was taken on October 29 and October 30.
A panel that studied transporation needs said earlier this year that Colorado would have a $13 billion shortfall over the next 20 years under current funding levels, the newspaper said.
